articles.title: Collective intelligence for AI-assisted chemical synthesis
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 19 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-026-10131-4Collective intelligence for AI-assisted chemical synthesis
articles.content: The exponential growth of scientific literature presents an increasingly acute challenge across disciplines. Hundreds of thousands of new chemical reactions are reported annually, yet translating them into actionable experiments becomes an obstacle1,2. Recent applications of large language models (LLMs) have shown promise3,4,5,6, but systems that reliably work for diverse transformations across de novo compounds have remained elusive. Here we introduce MOSAIC (Multiple Optimized Specialists for AI-assisted Chemical Prediction), a computational framework that enables chemists to harness the collective knowledge of millions of reaction protocols. MOSAIC is built upon the Llama-3.1-8B-instruct architecture7, training 2,498 specialized chemical experts within Voronoi-clustered spaces. This approach delivers reproducible and executable experimental protocols with confidence metrics for complex syntheses. With an overall 71% success rate, experimental validation demonstrates the realizations of over 35 novel compounds, spanning pharmaceuticals, materials, agrochemicals, and cosmetics. Notably, MOSAIC also enables the discovery of new reaction methodologies that are absent from the expert’s training, a cornerstone for advancing chemical synthesis. This scalable paradigm of partitioning vast domains into searchable expert regions enables a generalizable strategy for AI-assisted discovery wherever accelerating information growth outpaces efficient knowledge access and application.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant breakthrough in AI-assisted chemical synthesis, introducing MOSAIC, a computational framework that leverages collective intelligence and large language models to improve chemical reaction prediction and discovery. This advancement has broad implications for pharmaceuticals, materials, agrochemicals, and cosmetics, demonstrating tangible experimental success and enabling new reaction methodologies. The impact is meaningful for the general public through potential improvements in drug development and materials science, and the article provides sufficient detail on the technology and its validation.

articles.title: UK to consult on social media ban for under 16s
articles.summary: The government said it expected schools to be "phone-free by default" as a result of the announcement.
articles.content:
UK to consult on social media ban for under 16s

6 hours ago Share Save Laura Cress Technology reporter Share Save

Getty Images

The government will consult on whether social media should be banned for under-16s in the UK. It said "immediate action" would give Ofsted the power to check policies on phone use when it inspects schools, and it expected schools to be "phone-free by default" as a result of the announcement. A similar ban took effect in Australia in December 2025, the first of its kind in the world. Other countries are said to be considering such a law. It comes after more than 60 Labour MPs wrote to the prime minister about the issue, with the mother of murdered teenager Brianna Ghey also calling on the government to act.

"Some argue that vulnerable children need access to social media to find their community," Brianna's mother Esther Ghey wrote in a letter seen by the BBC. "As the parent of an extremely vulnerable and trans child, I strongly disagree. "In Brianna's case, social media limited her ability to engage in real-world social interactions. She had real friends, but she chose to live online instead." According to The Department of Science, Innovation and Technology, the consultation will "seek views from parents, young people and civil society" to determine the effectiveness of a ban. It would also look at whether more robust age checks could be implemented by social media firms, which could be forced to remove or limit features "which drive compulsive use of social media". And Ofsted will give tougher guidance to schools to reduce phone use - including telling staff not to use their devices for personal reasons in front of pupils. The government will respond to the consultation in the summer. Technology Secretary Liz Kendall said the laws in the Online Safety Act were "never meant to be the end point" and said she understood "parents still have serious concerns". "We are determined to ensure technology enriches children's lives, not harms them - and to give every child the childhood they deserve," she said. Conservative leader Kemi Badenoch has already said her party would introduce a social media ban for under-16s if it was in power. She said the consultation was "more dither and delay" from Labour. "The prime minister is trying to copy an announcement that the Conservatives made a week ago, and still not getting it right," she said. Liberal Democrat education spokeswoman Munira Wilson said there was "no time to waste in protecting our children from social media giants" and "this consultation risks kicking the can down the road yet again". National Education Union (NEU) general secretary Daniel Kebede called the move a "welcome shift". "Every day, parents and teachers see how social media shapes children's identities and attention long before they sit their GCSEs, pulling them into isolating, endless loops of content," he said.

Getty Images

The Association of School and College Leaders also welcomed the consultation on social media, but said the government had been "sluggish" in responding to the online risks posed to children. The union's general secretary Pepe Di'Iasio said there was "clearly a much wider problem of children and young people spending far too much time on screens and being exposed to inappropriate content". And Paul Whiteman, general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers, also welcomed the plans to consult on a potential social media ban. But he said the suggestion that Ofsted should "police" phones in schools was "deeply unhelpful and misguided". "School leaders need support from government, not the threat of heavy-handed inspection," he added.

'Not strong evidence'
articles.reasoning: The UK government's consultation on banning social media for under-16s aims to address the significant issue of children's mental health and wellbeing related to social media use. This policy initiative has broad societal impact, involving parents, schools, and regulators, and could lead to meaningful changes in how technology affects young people. The article provides detailed context about the consultation, stakeholder views, and international precedents, making it a substantive and focused story about a potential positive regulatory breakthrough.
articles.personality_title: UK government to consult on social media ban for under-16s
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The UK government is exploring ways to reduce the negative effects of social media on children. Concerns have grown about how social media affects young people's mental health and school life. Australia recently introduced a ban on social media use for under-16s, inspiring similar discussions in the UK.

**What happened** – The UK government announced it will consult the public on whether to ban social media for children under 16. This means they will ask parents, young people, and others for their views before making a decision. The government also wants schools to be mostly phone-free and plans to give Ofsted, the school inspection agency, more power to check phone policies. The consultation results will be shared in the summer.

**Impact** – This is an important step because it involves many groups working together—parents, schools, and social media companies—to protect children. If a ban or stronger rules are introduced, it could help children spend less time online and more time interacting in real life. It also shows the government is serious about tackling the risks of social media, like addiction and exposure to harmful content.

**What's next step** – After the consultation ends, the government will review the feedback and decide on the next actions. They might create new laws or rules for social media companies and schools. The conversation is ongoing, and other countries might watch the UK’s approach before making their own decisions.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The UK is considering a ban on social media for under-16s and stronger school phone rules to better protect children’s wellbeing online and offline.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le gouvernement britannique envisage d'interdire les réseaux sociaux aux moins de 16 ans
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Le gouvernement britannique cherche des solutions pour réduire les effets négatifs des réseaux sociaux sur les enfants. Les inquiétudes grandissent concernant la santé mentale des jeunes et leur vie scolaire. L'Australie a récemment interdit les réseaux sociaux aux moins de 16 ans, ce qui inspire des discussions similaires au Royaume-Uni.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Le gouvernement britannique a annoncé une consultation publique pour savoir s'il faut interdire les réseaux sociaux aux moins de 16 ans. Cela signifie qu'il demandera l'avis des parents, des jeunes et d'autres personnes avant de prendre une décision. Le gouvernement souhaite aussi que les écoles soient majoritairement sans téléphone et veut donner à Ofsted, l'agence d'inspection scolaire, plus de pouvoirs pour vérifier les règles sur les téléphones. Les résultats de la consultation seront publiés cet été.

**Impact** – C'est une étape importante car elle rassemble plusieurs groupes — parents, écoles et entreprises de réseaux sociaux — pour protéger les enfants. Si une interdiction ou des règles plus strictes sont mises en place, cela pourra aider les enfants à passer moins de temps en ligne et plus de temps à interagir dans la vie réelle. Cela montre aussi que le gouvernement prend au sérieux les risques des réseaux sociaux, comme l'addiction et l'exposition à des contenus nuisibles.

**Prochaine étape** – Après la consultation, le gouvernement examinera les avis recueillis et décidera des mesures suivantes. Il pourrait créer de nouvelles lois ou règles pour les entreprises de réseaux sociaux et les écoles. La discussion continue, et d'autres pays pourraient observer l'approche du Royaume-Uni avant de prendre leurs propres décisions.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Le Royaume-Uni envisage d'interdire les réseaux sociaux aux moins de 16 ans et de renforcer les règles sur les téléphones à l'école pour mieux protéger le bien-être des enfants en ligne et en dehors.
articles.personality_title_es: El gobierno del Reino Unido consulta sobre prohibir las redes sociales a menores de 16 años
articles.personality_presentation_es:

Crecen las preocupaciones sobre la salud mental de los jóvenes y su vida escolar. Australia recientemente prohibió las redes sociales para menores de 16 años, lo que ha inspirado discusiones similares en el Reino Unido.

Esto significa que preguntarán a padres, jóvenes y otras personas antes de tomar una decisión. También quieren que las escuelas sean en su mayoría sin teléfonos y planean dar a Ofsted, la agencia que inspecciona escuelas, más poder para revisar las políticas sobre teléfonos. Los resultados de la consulta se darán a conocer en verano.

**Impacto** – Este es un paso importante porque involucra a varios grupos—padres, escuelas y empresas de redes sociales—trabajando juntos para proteger a los niños. Si se introduce una prohibición o reglas más fuertes, podría ayudar a que los niños pasen menos tiempo en línea y más tiempo interactuando en la vida real. También muestra que el gobierno está tomando en serio los riesgos de las redes sociales, como la adicción y la exposición a contenido dañino.

**Próximo paso** – Después de la consulta, el gobierno revisará las opiniones recibidas y decidirá qué hacer. Podrían crear nuevas leyes o reglas para las empresas de redes sociales y las escuelas. La conversación sigue abierta, y otros países podrían observar lo que haga el Reino Unido antes de decidir.

**Resumen en una frase** – El Reino Unido está considerando prohibir las redes sociales a menores de 16 años y establecer reglas más estrictas sobre teléfonos en las escuelas para proteger mejor el bienestar de los niños dentro y fuera de línea.
